history.content:
If AI ever reaches the true level of intelligence to solve problems as complex as writing original code for original problems its trying to solve. We're likely to have a society where robots can literally do anything and either 

1) be in a whole lot of trouble. See: Ex Machina, iRobot, etc.

2) be in a paradise where problems are solved as quickly as they come to exist. Nobody will have a job -- robots will be plenty economically productive for all of us. 

All of this is probably way more than just 40 years into the distance so I'd say we're chilling.

If AI ever reaches the true level of intelligence to solve problems as complex as writing original code for original problems its trying to solve. We're likely to have a society where robots can literally do anything and either 

1) be in a whole lot of trouble. See: Ex Machina, iRobot, etc.

2) be in a paradise where problems are solved as quickly as they come to exist. Nobody will have a job -- robots will be plenty economically productive for all of us. 

All of this is probably way more than just 40 years into the distance so I'd say we're chilling. 

------

can you not take these trolls seriously?

If AI ever reaches the true level of intelligence to solve problems as complex as writing original code for original problems its trying to solve. We're likely to have a society where robots can literally do anything and either 

1) be in a whole lot of trouble. See: Ex Machina, iRobot, etc.

2) be in a paradise where problems are solved as quickly as they come to exist. Nobody will have a job -- robots will be plenty economically productive for all of us. 

All of this is probably way more than just 40 years into the distance so I'd say we're chilling.

children.subject: are you actually being serious right now
Yes, I am being serious. What will humans do if robots can do everything? If humans aren't needed, why will anyone pay them?

Look up universal basic income. This is an idea that has been delved into in a lot of depth. The point of AI is to help humans do work, not make us obsolete. There will certainly be plenty of people who won't be economically productive but that doesn't mean they shouldn't exist.
Kunal, congrats on building piazza 2.0 @2944. I'm looking forward to seeing it!
Also Kunal, of course people should exist. But how are they going to survive if they can't get jobs? Also, how are we going to pay for UBI? Robots don't pay taxes.
The government will own all production, ideally, to pay for UBI

I'm not the Anon above. In other words, we have to live under communism? Is capitalism impossible?

Also, congrats on piazza 2.0. A lot of people were ridiculing you on facebook but I knew you'd deliver.
Yeah thanks Kunal lol. Congrats; you're a meme.

With regards to capitalism being impossible... uhh, probably? Or some kind of new system? Or, most likely, the AI situation above most likely never comes to fruition, even though it might seem inevitable. AI may one day be capable of such feats but idk if our society is capable of sustaining a transition to one of the two above scenarios.

@anons: Ironically, I'm not a part of UCBMFET specifically to avoid distractions like this...

Kunal, I'm not talking about UCMFET.

Read this piazza post you created @2944. You said you're going to post piazza 2.0 soon!
Yeah just read this post Kunal: @2944. I mean you wrote it, so you already know about it.
Kunal we're all dying to see the code!

Isn't it a problem if no one has a job? The owners of production won't need to employ, and therefore pay, workers. In that case, how will humans survive? Perhaps we can work low-level jobs but the entire middle class will get destroyed.
What other implications will occur? And if the singularity is inevitable why don't we abandon AI? Seriously. AI is useful but if it threatens human survival, we don't need it.

This is a complicated issue and not really something that's easy to go in-depth in a Piazza post. I would recommend looking at case studies put out by IBM and other companies about why this development is occuring.
Not anon above. Seriously though, why are we even studying AI/CS 188 if eventually it can lead to human extinction? That's one of the worst decisions we as a species can make.
Because AI can do a lot of good, too!

Not OP here. What OP is saying is that AI (aka CS 188) can do a lot of good in the short term but in the long term it will lead to our extinction. I'd rather not pursue it / CS 188? Is this reasoning flawed.

You could certainly choose not to study it. That's totally personal. Sorry if I implied otherwise. :) 

OTOH, if you actually want to contribute to the debate / join the people who will influence AI regulation/ethics, you'd be infinitely better off making yourself an expert in AI/ethics. Look up "AI ethics" and you'll find an abundance of writing on it. One of the leading AI ethics institutes is actually right here in Berkeley!

Oh my god. Guys, seriously have some self confidence. Your Haas friend is describing the singularity, which will happen in 2040 at best, and will have a great deal more implications than programmers being useless. You still need a job for the next 20+ years and if you are really scared about the singularity, you can join technical standards organizations to regulate it.
Great response!

What a beautiful response Anon. Thank you (I am the OP).

How do you think the transition to a global economy will be changed by Trump's election? Will it change for better or worse?
Trump can talk what he wants but market forces will continue to demand for global development and automation. American manufacturing jobs aren't coming back

Thank you! Glad you liked it. 

I think the best thing to do right now is protect the worker, not their jobs (because those will disappear eventually). Unfortunately Trump plans on doing the opposite, or nothing. Considering Trump is adding fuel to fire for anti-intellectualism, racism, and xenophobia, I'd say he's going to make the transition a whole lot worse. Also his tax policies are probably just going to make income inequality worse, despite his claims.
Just wondering, why do you think Trump is racist. I would never have voted for a racist.
Are you saying you voted for trump?
Yes I voted for the PEOTUS.

Not sure which anon is which at this point, but I posted the original comment and the follow-up about Trump and racism. I would at the very least claim that Trump allows racism to have a voice in American politics again. Hell, Steve Bannon is his senior counselor. 

I really hope you're not trolling. This is Berkeley, but perhaps I shouldn't have brought up politics.

I'm a CS/CogSci double major - I think about these kinds of questions quite a bit. I've read a lot about AI and have a lot of opinions, but I'm just another undergrad like the rest of us. 

At our current level of technology, I personally think it is impossible to say if, when, or how the singularity will occur. I think it would be very risky (if not foolish) to make career choices based on the assumption that we'll have artificial general intelligence within the next 20 years. That doesn't mean we shouldn't be prepared - we should probably listen to Bostrom, Gates, and Musk's warning calls. This is a great summary of the dangers of AI and this is a great presentation explaining why it might not all be so bad, if you want to read up on it.

That being said, one thing we do know is that we are in a full throttle transition from a product economy to an information economy. This is part of globalization - as it becomes easier and cheaper to move products, people, and information, the average laborer becomes easily replaceable. Innovators, scientists, and engineers become all the more important (as a side note, I think this explains a lot of global political events). I also think AI is just a part of this transition, and who knows where it will take us. I think a universal basic income/techno-communist utopia and Ex Machina/Matrix-esque dystopia are both equally unlikely, but then again, what do I know.

In a way, your friend is right. The average coder/software engineer is probably replaceable. We all know making a website or an iOS/Android app isn't that difficult. Then again, if we can replace coders, we can probably replace many low-level positions in the business sector. Suck it haas-hole. 

In another sense, I think your friend is very wrong. In a world with perfect information, product, and labor distribution, we will need people who really understand how the world works in order to create new goods and services. We will need people specifically with STEM degrees to keep pushing the limits of human knowledge and achievement. Admittedly, we'll probably also still need businessmen and managers to run our companies.

I chose to pursue a career in the former because I find it far more interesting and rewarding, but that doesn't mean business can't be. Ultimately, if you really enjoy EECS, I see absolutely no reason why you should not pursue it. I think it is a wonderful field with a lot of room for innovation and I'm very excited to be a part of it.

history.content:
Yesterday I asked my Haas friend why he didn't pursue EECS, even though he loves EECS and it's his dream career.


"Because", he said, "in twenty years we'll have robots that can write 10x more useful code 10x as fast as humans, with 10x fewer bugs". This is a guy who got an A+ in every CS lower div class.

Is he correct? Are we humans doomed to re-implementing programs robots / software has already written?
history.subject: Will programmers be useless in 20 years?
